title: 106_s311
content:
The Disabled Veterans Memorial is authorized to be established on Federal land in the District of Columbia to honor disabled veterans who served in the Armed Forces. The memorial must comply with standards for commemorative works on Federal lands. Expenses for the memorial will be paid for. The Disabled Veterans' LIFE Memorial Foundation is responsible for accepting contributions and paying expenses for the memorial. No Federal funds can be used for the memorial's expenses. Any excess funds will be deposited with the Secretary of the Treasury. TITLE II--COMMEMORATIVE WORKS ACT AMENDMENTS

SEC. 201. SHORT TITLE

    This title may be cited as the ``Commemorative Works Clarification 
and Revision Act of 2000''.

SEC. 202. REFERENCE TO COMMEMORATIVE WORKS ACT.

    In this title, the term ``Act'' refers to the Commemorative Works 
Act of 1986, as amended (Public Law 99-652; 40 U.S.C. 1001 et seq.).

SEC. 203. CLARIFICATIONS AND REVISIONS TO THE ACT. The Commemorative Works Act of 1986 is amended to encourage the location of commemorative works within the urban fabric of the District of Columbia. Amendments include changes to definitions, sponsors, and designated areas on maps. The Commemorative Works Act of 1986 is amended to define the term "Reserve" as the central axis of the Mall in Washington D.C. and make adjustments to the criteria for commemorating military engagements. The Commemorative Works Act of 1986 is amended to establish the National Capital Memorial Commission and modify the criteria for commemorating military engagements. The Commemorative Works Act of 1986 is amended to establish the National Capital Memorial Commission and modify criteria for commemorating military engagements. Amendments include changes to the roles of the Commissioner of Public Buildings Service and the Secretary of Defense, as well as updates to sections 5 and 6 of the Act. The Commemorative Works Act of 1986 is amended to establish the National Capital Memorial Commission and modify criteria for commemorating military engagements. Amendments include changes to the roles of the Commissioner of Public Buildings Service and the Secretary of Defense, as well as updates to sections 5 and 6 of the Act. Sites for commemorative works within the Reserve are no longer authorized after January 1, 2000. Section 7 of the Act is amended to change terminology and include new paragraphs regarding commemorative works primarily designed as museums. The Commemorative Works Act of 1986 is amended to establish the National Capital Memorial Commission and modify criteria for commemorating military engagements. Amendments include changes to the roles of the Commissioner of Public Buildings Service and the Secretary of Defense, as well as updates to sections 5 and 6 of the Act. Sites for commemorative works within the Reserve are no longer authorized after January 1, 2000. Section 7 of the Act is amended to include new paragraphs regarding commemorative works primarily designed as museums. The National Capital Planning Commission and the Commission of Fine Arts may develop criteria or guidelines for each site to ensure the design of the commemorative work aligns with the Act's purposes. Donor contributions to commemorative works shall not be acknowledged as part of the commemorative work or its site. Section 8 of the Act is amended to replace "person" with "sponsor" in specified subsections. The Commemorative Works Act of 1986 is amended to establish the National Capital Memorial Commission and modify criteria for commemorating military engagements. Amendments include changes to the roles of the Commissioner of Public Buildings Service and the Secretary of Defense, as well as updates to sections 5 and 6 of the Act. Sites for commemorative works within the Reserve are no longer authorized after January 1, 2000. Section 7 of the Act is amended to include new paragraphs regarding commemorative works primarily designed as museums. The National Capital Planning Commission and the Commission of Fine Arts may develop criteria or guidelines for each site to ensure the design of the commemorative work aligns with the Act's purposes. Donor contributions to commemorative works shall not be acknowledged as part of the commemorative work or its site. Section 8 of the Act is amended to replace "person" with "sponsor" in specified subsections. Additionally, construction permits require sponsors to donate 10 percent of the total estimated cost for perpetual maintenance and preservation of the commemorative work. The Commemorative Works Act of 1986 is amended to establish the National Capital Memorial Commission and modify criteria for commemorating military engagements. Money provided by a sponsor for maintenance shall be credited to separate accounts in the Treasury or the National Park Foundation. The Secretary of the Treasury or the National Park Foundation can make these funds available for maintenance of commemorative works. The Secretary or Administrator cannot request funds exceeding the total money in the account established under paragraph (1) or (2). An inventory of funds must be maintained. Funds provided are available without further appropriation and remain available until expended. The sponsor must submit an annual report of operations and financial statements audited by an independent certified public accountant. Section 9 of the Act is repealed, and Section 10 is amended. Section 10 of the Act (40 U.S.C. 1010) is amended to set a seven-year expiration period for legislative authority for a commemorative work, unless construction permits are issued or final design approvals obtained. The National Capital Planning Commission and the Commission of Fine Arts must approve 75 percent of the required funds for a memorial before the legislative authority can be extended for up to three years. A new master plan will guide future memorial locations outside the Reserve for the next 50 years. SEC. 204. PREVIOUSLY APPROVED MEMORIALS.

This title does not apply to memorials approved before the enactment date under the Commemorative Works Act of 1986. The Senate passed the bill on July 10, 2000, authorizing the establishment of a memorial by the Disabled Veterans' LIFE Memorial Foundation in the District of Columbia or its environs.
